note: Dozens are executed.
title: 63 Hundreds—mostly Jews—throughout the USSR are subjected to show trials for “economic crimes
The Student Struggle for Soviet Jewry is founded in New York

Yuli Daniel and Andrei Sinyavsky are sentenced to seven years of hard labor for publishing satirical poems abroad. Public protests in both the Soviet Union and the West mark the beginning of a growing wave of open dissent, the “democratic movement
The Soviet Union actively supports Egypt and Syria in the run-up to the Six-Day War—diplomatically, economically, and with arms supplies
A group of sixteen refuseniks plot to hijack a plane and fly to Israel but are arrested and tried for treason. The ensuing world public outcry leads to a loosening of emigration restrictions
Major North American Jewish organizations found the National Council for Soviet Jewry
Nobel laureate Alexander Solzhenitsyn is exiled from the Soviet Union for his criticism of the regime

note: At the same time, the USSR largely ignored them, and emigration rates decreased.
title: The signing of the Helsinki Accords, which ostensibly would bind the Soviet Union to uphold civil rights, provides validation and moral support for the Jewish campaign to secure religious, cultural, and emigration rights
The USSR invades Afghanistan, the United States imposes sanctions, and the USSR puts the brakes on Jewish emigration; the annual average drops from twenty-five thousand to one thousand
General Secretary Gorbachev introduces the policy of glasnost, calling for greater openness and transparency in government
Some 250,000 protesters gather in Washington during General Secretary Gorbachev’s visit, demanding that he give Soviet Jews the freedom to emigrate
The Communist governments in Romania
Elections are held in the Soviet Union in the context of a new, democratic constitution
Emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel jumps from 13,000 in
The Soviet Union is dissolved
In Israel, Yisrael Ba’aliyah, a Russian immigrants’ party headed by former refuseniks Nathan Sharansky and Yuli Edelstein, receives 5.7 percent of the vote, yielding seven Knesset seats
The Russian Jewish Congress is established, followed by the creation of parallel organizations in other former Soviet republics

note: A detailed account from the First World War until 1976.
title: The Russian Jew under the Tsars and Soviets
Silent No More”: Saving the Jews of Russia, The American Jewish Effort, 1967–1989
An analysis of the various players and events in the Western struggle for Soviet Jews
A Second Exodus: The American Movement to Free Soviet Jews
A collection of papers on the history of the struggle
The Jews of Russia and the Soviet Union, 1881 to the Present
A detailed account, right up to the end of Soviet rule
Red Shtetl
An example of how Jewish life in the periphery continued under Communism

note: These volumes have not been cited in the individual chapters.
title: Each chapter contains suggestions for further reading on the specific historical period under consideration. This bibliography includes general histories, covering longer spans, that can be consulted for additional background or different perspectives on any period
A History of the Jewish People
A thousand pages, divided into six chronological sections, each written by a leading historian of the period

note: organized chronologically, from the Bible to the present.
title: Cultures of the Jews: A New History
A collection of scholarly essays on Jewish cultures

container-title: Mansoor, Manahem. Jewish History and Thought: An Introduction
note: A compact chronological survey of Jewish thinkers, writers, and ideas, in outline form.
title: A History of the Jews
A comprehensive survey from Abraham to the present by a Catholic journalist—a unique contemporaneous attempt to understand Jewish history as an “outsider
A History of Judaism
A two-volume survey, with a focus on the development of thought and belief
Ideas of Jewish History
An anthology of different approaches to Jewish historiography through the ages
Wanderings: Chaim Potok’s History of the Jews
A survey of Jewish history, with emphasis on the premodern periods
A History of the Jews: From Earliest Times through the Six Day War
A survey, through the Six-Day War
The Story of the Jews: Finding the Words, 1000 BCE–1492 CE
A noted art historian’s off-the-beaten-track account through 1492
Judaism’s Great Debates
Brief accounts of formative controversies, including debates relevant to this book
Eternal Faith, Eternal People
A survey to the mid-twentieth century, emphasizing the development of thought and belief
